Food is deliberately 'denatured' when a substance, known as a 'denaturant', is
added to render the food unpleasant to consume or poisonous. Aversive
agentsâprimarily bitterants and pungent agentsâare used to produce an unpleasant
flavor. For example, the bitterant denatonium might be added to food used in the
laboratory, where the food is not intended for human consumption. A poison may
be added as an even more powerful deterrent. For example, methanol is added to
ethanol to produce denatured alcohol. The addition of poisonous methanol renders
denatured alcohol unfit for consumption. Thus denatured alcohol is not subject
to the taxes alcoholic beverages are subject to.
